Award.AwardTitle: G8 Initiative: Ink-jet Printed Single-Crystal Organic Photovoltaics

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This multinational research project will explore manufacturing issues for the production of low-cost electronic devices, focusing primarily on solar cells for power generation. At a fundamental level, the researchers will intensively screen current generation materials under the rigorous conditions necessary for low-cost, high-speed device fabrication using printing methods. Data from these initial investigations will feed into the materials design part of this project, to optimize molecular structure specifically for use in inkjet printing. Throughout the process, in-depth studies of the materials in high-quality crystals will yield the intrinsic electronic properties of the compounds prepared, which will be used as a benchmark for the electronic properties found in printed devices; the ultimate goal is to develop a materials set that performs just as well when formed under high-speed manufacturing processes as it does in careful slow-film-growth laboratory experiments. The new material sets will be used to create solar cells, solid-state lighting panels and flat-panel displays using low-cost inkjet printing instead of traditional (and expensive) photolithography techniques.

The results of this project will be immensely useful to the manufacture of low-cost, flexible electronics, and industrial collaborations to this end are part of the project. Ultra-low-cost solar cells in particular will do much to alleviate many of the energy supply issues faced worldwide. Furthermore, this project will exploit chemical feedstocks derived from plant-based sources, rather than petroleum sources, to help harness the Nation's impressive agricultural infrastructure to solving renewable power generation issues. It is hoped that these reduced cost solar panels, which inherently offer a much more rapid return on investment, will enhance the market's adoption of renewable energy technologies.

Performance_Institution.Name: UK Center for Applied Energy Research

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on two critical areas to increase the efficiency of low-cost, renewable power generation. In order to increase the amount of light falling on a solar panel, we investigated a process known as "singlet fission", which converts high-energy light (for example, the kind of ultra-violet light that leads skin to burn in the sun) into lower-energy light of twice the intensity. Applying materials that undergo singlet fission to standard solar cells will increase their power output, due to the increased intensity of light. To realize this improvement, we had to invent new materials that undergo singlet fission efficiently, as well as methods to process them into high-quality films on flexible surfaces to allow us to apply them to a variety of solar power generators. Further, to make the use of this technology economical, we needed to create methods to make these films that could be used inexpensively at large scale - such as printing or spray-painting techniques.

In the final year of the project, we demonstrated three classes of materials that undergo singlet fission rapidly and with 100% efficiency. We also worked with researchers in Greece and the United Kingdom on methods to form high-quality films of these materials by two different spray-coating techniques. In the waning months of the project, we were able to begin looking at the final hurdle to the implementation of this technology, the efficient extraction of the low-energy light generated by singlet fission to generate power.

The final project period led to enhanced training of a post-doctoral scholar, to prepare him for a future career in academia. We presented our approach to improve solar power generation in numerous high-profile publications, at several conferences in the U.S. and Europe, and we have developed a module to present the approach we take to enhancing renewable energy generation for presentation to grade-school students and State legislators. 

Over the full project period, as my research group developed new materials, we collaborated with a wide range of research groups (particularly at Cambridge in the UK, but also with groups at Columbia, Wake Forest, Princeton, Penn State, KAUST in Saudi Arabia, and Aristotle University in Greece) to understand the intricate relationship between molecular structure and performance in our desired applications, and to begin to understand the parameters needed to create high-quality, large-area films of the materials required for deployment in usable devices. Because the materials we developed are multi-functional, along with the main goals of this project in efficient power generation we also investigated the use of our compounds in durable, flexible displays for personal electronic devices, sensors, and flexible electronic circuits. In the waning months of the project, we began to explore the use of computational approaches to design new materials on the computer, to rapidly accelerate the development of new high-performance compounds to decrease the amount of chemical effort (and corresponding waste generation) of current approaches.

These research efforts led to the training of a substantial number of graduate, undergraduate, post-doctoral, and even high-school researchers at all involved institutions in a highly interdisciplinary research field, broadening their perspective outside their disciplinary experience and preparing them for careers in today's high-productivity workplace.  Of the high school students involved in this project, on was awarded first place in Chemistry the Intel International Science and Engineering Fair. All of the undergraduate researchers supported under this work have either gone on to graduate (Chemistry) or professional (medical, dental) schools, or straight into industrial jobs in chemistry. The graduate students involved have all obtained their Ph.D. degrees and moved on to post-doctoral research, while the post-doctoral scholar employed is now in the midst of an academic job search, to become a professor of chemistry.

More broadly, the materials and techniques developed under this project are now being used by researchers across the U.S., Europe, and Asia for as the organic electronics community continues to find routes over the hurdles to development of new forms of flexible electronics and power generating devices. 


Last Modified: 11/29/2016
Modified by: John E Anthony
